Class FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O>

java.lang.Object
functions.FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O>
Type Parameters:
I - the input type
O - the output type
Enclosing class:
FunctionGenerator<I,O>
public static class FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> extends Object
A builder for creating generated functions using descriptions, scenarios, test classes, or custom strategies.

This class provides a fluent interface for incrementally configuring the parameters of a FunctionGenerator and creating it using the build() method.

  • Constructor Details

    • Builder

      public Builder()

  • Method Details

    • build

      public Function<I,O> build()
      Builds and returns a Function using the configured parameters.
      Returns:
      a Function<I, O> instance. When calling apply() on the generated function, the function will throw exceptions as defined by the user via withPreExecutionCheck and withExecutionError. Exceptions thrown are also dependent on the FunctionGenerationStrategy selected. An IllegalStateException will be thrown if the function fails to parse the JSON string from the function generation strategy into the selected output type.
      Throws:
      ConfigurationException - if required parameters are missing or invalid

    • withInputType

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withInputType(Class<I> inputType)
      Sets the input type for the function. The input type can be specified by calling this method once. Calling this method multiple times will override the previous input type. Must coincide with the input type of the function.
      Parameters:
      inputType - the class of the input type I
      Returns:
      this builder instance

    • withOutputType

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withOutputType(Class<O> outputType)
      Sets the output type for the function. The output type can be specified by calling this method once, calling this method multiple times will override the previous output type. Must coincide with the output type of the function.
      Parameters:
      outputType - the class of the output type O
      Returns:
      this builder instance

    • withDescription

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withDescription(String description)
      Sets the description for the function. The description of the function can be constructed by calling this method multiple times. Each call will append the provided description to the existing description.
      Parameters:
      description - the natural language description of the function
      Returns:
      this builder instance

    • withScenarios

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withScenarios(List<Scenario<I,O>> scenarios)
      Sets the scenarios for the function. Multiple sets of scenarios can be added by calling this method multiple times. Each call will append the provided scenarios to the existing list of scenarios.
      Parameters:
      scenarios - the list of input-output scenarios
      Returns:
      this builder instance

    • withStrategy

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withStrategy(FunctionGenerationStrategy strategy)
      Sets the strategy for generating the function. The strategy can be constructed by calling this method once, if called multiple times, the last strategy will be used.
      Parameters:
      strategy - the FunctionGenerationStrategy to use
      Returns:
      this builder instance

    • withPreExecutionCheck

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withPreExecutionCheck(Exception exceptionToThrow, Predicate<I> condition)
      Adds a validation to the function inputs. This validation ensures that the input is checked before the function body is executed, enabling early failure when invalid input is detected.

      The provided validation includes a predicate that defines the condition under which the specified exception will be thrown. If the predicate evaluates to true, the exception is thrown immediately, and the function does not proceed. This behavior allows for fail-fast mechanisms to ensure invalid inputs are caught early.

      Early Failure Example:

      
 // Build the function generator with the validation condition
 Function<String, Integer> generator = FunctionGenerator.<String, Integer>builder()
         .withDescription("Parses an integer from a string")
         .withInputType(String.class)
         .withOutputType(Integer.class)
         .withStrategy(strategy)
         // Define a validation to check for null input
         .withPreExecutionCheck(
             new NullPointerException("Input cannot be null"),
             input -> input == null
         );

 // When invoking the function with null input, the predicate triggers early failure
 try {
     Integer result = generator.build().apply(null);
 } catch (NullPointerException e) {
     System.out.println(e.getMessage()); // Output: Input cannot be null
 }
      Parameters:
      exceptionToThrow - the exception instance to throw when the condition is met
      condition - the predicate that defines when the exception should be thrown
      Returns:
      this builder instance
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if exceptionToThrow or condition is null

    • withExecutionError

      public FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withExecutionError(Exception exceptionToThrow, String conditionDescription)
      Adds an error condition to the function. This error condition is described using a natural language condition, which is interpreted and enforced by the backend during the function's execution. Multiple error conditions can be added by calling this method multiple times. The order in which the error conditions are checked is not guaranteed.

      Unlike the predicates provided in the withPreExecutionCheck method, this condition is not validated before the function starts execution. Instead, it is evaluated during execution as the backend processes the input and applies the described condition.

      Execution-Time Failure Example:

      
 // Build the function generator with a backend-interpreted error condition
 Function<String, String> generator = FunctionGenerator.<String, String>builder()
         .withDescription("Converts a string to uppercase")
         .withInputType(String.class)
         .withOutputType(String.class)
         .withStrategy(strategy)
         .withExecutionError(
             new IllegalArgumentException("Input contains prohibited content"),
             "Input string contains a bad word"
         );

 // When invoking the function, the backend will process the input
 // and may trigger the exception if the condition is met
 try {
     String result = generator.build().apply("This is a badword");
 } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
     System.out.println(e.getMessage()); // Output: Input contains prohibited content
 }

      Note: Since this condition is interpreted by the backend, its enforcement depends on the model's ability to understand and process the described condition correctly.

      Parameters:
      exceptionToThrow - the exception instance to throw when the condition is met
      conditionDescription - a natural language description of the condition under which the exception should be thrown
      Returns:
      this builder instance
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if exceptionToThrow or conditionDescription is null

    • withTestClass

      public <T> FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withTestClass(Class<T> testClass)
      Configures the builder to analyze the specified test class and extract information about its annotated test methods to assist in generating more accurate functions based on the test cases. Multiple test classes can be added by calling this method multiple times. Each test class will be analyzed to extract test methods annotated with @Test. The quality of the resulting function will depend on the quality test cases available.

      Usage:

      
 Function<Integer, Boolean> isEven = FunctionGenerator.<Integer, Boolean>builder()
     .withInputType(Integer.class)        // Specify input type
     .withOutputType(Boolean.class)       // Specify output type
     .withStrategy(functionGenerator)    // Specify strategy
     .withTestClass(IsEvenTest.class)    // Specify the test class
     .withTestClass(IsEvenTestExceptions.class)    // Specify an additional test class
     .build();

      Exceptions:

      • IllegalArgumentException if the class cannot be parsed or if errors occur during the decompilation or parsing process.

      Example Test Class:

      
 public class IsEvenTest {
     @Before
     public void setup() { ... }

     @After
     public void teardown() { ... }

     @Test
     public void testIsEven() {
         assertEquals(true, isEven(4));
     }
 
     @Test
     public void testIsOdd() {
         assertEquals(false, isEven(3));
     }
 }
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the test class being analyzed.
      Parameters:
      testClass - The Class<T> object representing the test class to analyze.
      Returns:
      The current instance of the builder for method chaining.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the provided test class cannot be processed due to parsing or decompilation errors.
      See Also:
      • Test
      • Before
      • After

    • withTestPackage

      public <T> FunctionGenerator.Builder<I,O> withTestPackage(Package testPackage)
      Configures the builder to analyze all test classes within the specified package and use the test method details to generate the function. Test classes from test package can be constructed by calling this method once. This method retrieves all classes in the given package, processes each class individually as if by using the withTestClass(Class) method, and extracts information about annotated test methods. Each call to this method will add the new test classes to the function for training.

      This functionality is useful when test cases are organized into packages, the quality of the resulting function will depend on the quality test cases available.

      This functionality is useful when test cases are organized into packages, allowing for bulk processing of all test classes in a single invocation.

      Usage:

      
 Function<Integer, Boolean> isEven = FunctionGenerator.<Integer, Boolean>builder()
     .withInputType(Integer.class)        // Specify input type
     .withOutputType(Boolean.class)       // Specify output type
     .withStrategy(functionGenerator)    // Specify strategy
     .withTestPackage(IsEvenTests.class.getPackage()) // Specify the package containing test classes
     .build();

      Exceptions:

      • IllegalArgumentException if the package cannot be processed or if errors occur while retrieving or processing classes.

      Requirements:

      • Package names should be valid and resolvable at runtime.

      Example Test Package:

      
 package client_code.tests;
 
 public class IsEvenTest {
     @Before
     public void setup() { ... }
 
     @Test
     public void testIsEven() {
         assertEquals(true, isEven(4));
     }
 }
 
 public class IsOddTest {
     @Test
     public void testIsOdd() {
         assertEquals(false, isOdd(3));
     }
 }
      Parameters:
      testPackage - The Package object representing the package containing test classes to analyze.
      Returns:
      The current instance of the builder for method chaining.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the specified package cannot be processed or errors occur while retrieving or processing classes.
      See Also:
      • withTestClass(Class)
      • Package
